Alan and Blokes 'n' Sheilas,

"Glazed surface".  Now that's interesting.  How was the glaze produced??  For
such a feature to have lasted a few centuries it must be very hard, which
suggests to me that it was produced by heating the tsuba in a furnace to induce
an oxidation on the surface that became "the glaze".  If chemically induced it
would show wear, surely.  Just some mild speculation over my breakfast oats...

Barry Thomas.

Ron,
There is a Naokatsu tsuba currently on sale at Aoi Art: FO550 - March 17, I
quite like these copies, I had one by Gassan Sadakazu which attempted to copy
Nobuie's glazed surface.
Alan

  ----- Original Message -----
  From: Ron Hartmann

  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba kantei 3


  Jim -

  Funny, but this work reminded me somewhat of Jirotaro Naokatsu is style.
Realizing he copied Nobuie and seeing the super quality of this wonderful tsuba,
I go along with the Nobuie call for it. (Sorry, Naokatsu san)

  Interesting treatment of the very large/very small-ish hitsu-ana. I would find
it interesting to read more comment on that particular feature "in general."

  Ron
  STL
